Posts.Content: I can provide what my pelvic floor physical therapist told me to do. 3 sets of 10 exercises, one each in the morning and evening while laying on my side in bed (this is a no load position, no pressure on the bladder or muscles) and one during the day while either sitting or standing. Anything more would fatigue the muscles. I was told to sit and pee as this relaxes the pelvic muscles and works on muscle memory. I was also told to NOT stop and start the flow. My PT hooked sensors to provide biofeedback and I watched on a screen during the exercises, I was clinching too hard and this feedback showed how much is actually needed. As for fluids, I was told no caffeine , alcohol, citrus juices or anything that would cause bladder spasms. I balked at the no caffeine and she said if you drink a lot of water to dilute it then you’ll be fine. For the first week after the cath came out I stuck to water only. I had somewhat bladder control right after the cath came out, the bladder would hold urine and I could pee on demand but still had stress incontinence. Nights were dry with 1 or 2 trips to the bathroom. At about 4 weeks there was a significant difference in the stress incontinence, it was a lot less frequent. I am down to 1 pad during the day and 1 pad at night although not needed unless I dribble some sitting up to get up. I have been drinking 1 cup of coffee in the morning and maybe a beer or two on the weekend and I really don’t see a big difference. Starting back to working out seemed to set me back a little, I think the stress of using the elliptical fatigued the muscles earlier in the day which caused more stress leakage. I found myself holding back the urge to dribble while working out. Hope this helps

Posts.Title: Path Report

Posts.Content: I am 51 yo and finished 38 sessions of radiation in July. After my daily sessions my bowels would feel a little irritated. My sessions were at 4:30 pm daily and then I would eat dinner around 5:30. By 6:30 my food was gone, in the toilet. My bowel movements went from 1 a day to 4 or 5 a day. Everything from diarrhea to soft but never hard. I did not feel fatigued or run down. It is normal, everyone has a different reaction but what you described is more of the extreme of the side effects. The part that isnt "normal" is the strange feeling since the biopsy. I would consult your Urologist for a second opinion. All my side effects went away 30-45 days after the radiation ended.

Posts.Content: I had pain and tingling like needles poking me in the left thigh on the outside. Almost like a Charlie horse but instead of a cramp it was like I described above. I think it had something to do with the sciatic nerve. Mine went away after a few days. Clots from DVT are usually in the lower legs, not the upper thighs.

Posts.Content: I too am trying to get to the Mayo for a C11/Choline. My last PSA was 2.1 I just visited MD Anderson, the medical Oncologist could not recommend the Choline one way or another because she was not that familiar with it. She recommended HT for my particular case, including the "Finite" clinical trial. I was told that the Sodium Acetate for mainly to see bone markers for mets. My local Uro put in the referral for Mayo, waiting to see if its approved.

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: Hello Thanks for the replies so far. I appreciate the feedback. I had my appointment with my urologist on the 25th. He explained a lot but, bottom line, he recommends surgery and he mainly does open. He said he has performed robotic with the DaVinci as well. All in all, about 100 of each. This is a military surgeon since I am active duty Army. He offerd to use the DaVinci at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio Tx if I desired but I think with him only having 100 and it is not his primary tool, I'll pass. The other option is open surgery at Fort Hood Tx. I do have a consult in for a Radiation Oncologist but it may take a few weeks. I have also been approved for a consult at Scott & White in Temple Tx where there are two very good doctors that use DaVinci exclusively. One issue that concerned me, my doctor stated that he would not attempt to spare the right side nerve bundle becuase of the PNI, too risky that it has spread to the nerves. I think I need a 2nd opinion on that one. He also told me there really isnt a difference in recovery between open and laparoscopic. This is contrary to what I have read. I ordered Dr. Patrick Walsh's book and will read it cover to cover. As an aside to a topic above, I was told that if radiation therapy is used first it may damage the prostrate and surrounding organs with scaring that will make it next to impossible for a surgeon to remove the prostrate.

Posts.Title: Post Op

Posts.Content: We'll I guess I made it to the other side. Had my laparoscopic radical prostatectomy on 9 April 2013 compliments of mr. da vinci. Doc said it looked contained but obviously we have to wait for the path report. Discharged the next day after noon, only took a tylenol 3 one time the next day. Already passed gas and had a good BM on day 3. Getting used to Mr. Cath, not really a big deal anymore. Scheduled to have it removed on the 17th, 8 days after. Hoping for a good path report. G

Posts.Title: My Turn :)

Posts.Content: Hello, I was just diagnosed on 20 Feb 13. I am scheduled to see the urologist again on the 25th. I have been doing my own research until then. I know my doctor is going to recommend a radical prostatectomy but I am not so sure I want to go that route initially. It appears to be contained to just the right side of the prostrate but I am going to ask if a CT or bone scan will help with a more definitive answer. Anyone have any experience with the Cyber Knife? I appreciate any and all advice. Here is my info: 48 yo PSA History 23 Jan 2004 .08 14 Jan 2011 2.69 28 Dec 2012 6.3 02 Jan 2013 6.1 11% Free DRE: Firmness to R side Biopsy 11 Feb 13: 12 Core samples 6 Positive for Adenocarcinoma Right mid, base and apex (left Benign) Right Base: Gleason 3+3=6, 15% of sample, Perineural invasion present Right Mid: Gleason 3+3=6, 60% of sample Right Apex: Gleason 3+4=7, 25% of sample Thanks

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hello, We are the same age and I just had a Da Vinci procedure last week. In fact, my cath was removed yesterday. I think you are doing the right thing based on age and biopsy findings. My report came back showing the cancer was confined to the prostate so I am glad I made this decision. If there were positive margins or other findings to show there was still some cancer remaining, I would seek radiation treatment after the surgery. IMO, this is the best way for survival. Good luck G
